profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-01-04 12:03:30 -0500.

did.abstract: The Artifact Collection is an artificial collection created in 2001, which consists of materials relating to Tufts University and people associated with Tufts University; artifacts from ancient cultures and modern; and manuscripts, prints, and other texts, all dating circa 2150 BCE – 2007 CE. Materials included in this collection are coins; cuneiform tablets and cones; illuminated manuscripts; leaves from early printed books; maps; paintings; prints; sculptures; textiles; and other artifacts.
did.langmaterial: The majority of textual item in this collection are in English. There are also some items in Akkadian, Egyptian, Flemish, French, German, Hebrew, Latin, Italian, and Sumerian.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged into six series: Tufts materials; Coins; Cuneiform, scarabs, memorial slab, and tomb figure; Manuscript, printed, and book history materials; Portraits, paintings, and sculptures; and other artifacts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The artifact collection is an artificial collection created in 2001, which consists of materials relating to Tufts University and people associated with Tufts University; artifacts from ancient cultures and modern; and manuscripts, prints, and other texts, all dating circa 2150 BCE – 2007 CE. Material relating to Tufts University includes plaques, trophies, and medals; jewelry; textiles; papers and printed materials; and other objects belonging or relating to Tuft University and people associated with Tufts University. Artifacts from ancient cultures include examples of papyrus, cuneiform, scarabs, memorial slabs, a tomb figure, and coins representing varied cultures such as Egypt, Sumer, the Akkadian Empire, and Greece. There are also examples of coins from modern cultures. Artifacts in this collection include sculptures, a bamboo flute, and a cannon ball. Texts and printed materials include autographs and correspondence; illuminated and early manuscripts; leaves from early printed books, some with woodblock illustrations; governmental documents; maps; painting and prints; Illuminated and early manuscript leaves and leaves from early printed books are mainly from educational or religious texts and are in various languages, including English, Hebrew, Latin, German, Italian, French and Flemish.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Tufts Archival Research Center is the Tufts University steward for all archival records and materials of significant and historical relevance to the college.

The collection began as the University Archives, which were incorporated in 1965 by the Tufts University Board of Trustees (Annual Reports 1965-1988). Previously, the position of archivist was loosely created in 1959 as a means of processing and acquiring important university and student records for preservation. This role was filled by Tufts history professor and historian Russell L. Miller, who also wrote the Tufts University history "Light on the Hill." The archives were considered a department of the University Library (known as Eaton and then Wessell at that time), overseen by the College of Arts, Sciences and Engineering.

The university's archives were first kept in Eaton Library, but moved to the Wessell Library building in 1965. Originals of some records were sent to vaults in Ballou Hall for storage. In 1991, due to budget issues, the university archivist was laid off. When the office was reopened in 1997, it was as the University Archives and Special Collections, also located as a department within the Tisch Library.

In July 2001, Digital Collections and Archives (DCA) was created when the University Archives was tasked with developing a Tufts Digital Library. The department moved from the College of Arts, Science and Engineering to the Central Administration, directed by the University Provost. The Special Collections department remained under Tisch Library.
In January 2023, DCA was renamed Tufts Archival Research Center (TARC) to better reflect the mission and services offered by the department.
TARC is currently physically housed in the Tisch Library building.

processinfo.head: Processing status
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Archives and Research Assistant Rose Koven under the supervision of Collections Management Archivist Adrienne Pruitt in 2019. Materials were intellectually organized into 6 series of related materials, and two of those series were broken down into subseries. Titles on some objects were modified to reflect current archival standards and to better describe the objects, and dates were added or correctly when applicable.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproductions and Use" on the Digital Collections and Archives website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish. No documentation is available regarding the intellectual property rights in this collection.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Artifact Collection, circa 2150 BCE – 2007 CE. Tufts University. Digital Collections and Archives. Medford, MA.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains artifacts and printed materials dated circa 1700 -- 2007 that are associated with Tufts University in general and as well as with people associated with Tufts University. Artifacts include jewelry such as pins and watches; plaques, trophies, and medal; textiles such as Tufts apparel and clothing belonging to the Tufts family; materials gathered from Alonzo Ames miner's birthplace; and other objects such as elephant figurines and copper engraving plates for Tufts diplomas and certificates.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged into 6 sub-series: Alonzo Ames Miner materials; Jewelry; Other objects; Papers and printed materials; Plaques, trophies, and medals; and Textiles.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This series is open for research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains materials gathered from the birthplace of Alonzo Ames Miner, Tufts's second president (1862 – 1875), as well as stamped envelopes addressed to him and a silver spoon engraved with his name, circa 1700 – 1927.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: No order has been imposed on this sub-series.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This sub-series is open for research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Morton Prince was a professor of nervous diseases at Tufts from 1902 until 1912, when he was appointed professor emeritus and awarded an honorary degree. (Taken from Henry H. Banks' "A Century of Excellence: The History of Tufts University School of Medicine 1893 –1993 p107-108).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains papers and printed materials related to Tufts University and people associated with Tufts University dating circa 1767 – 1969. This includes matriculation books; the original deed for the land Tufts on which Tufts stands; maps and building plans; a codicil to the will of Rebeccah Davidson; and other Tufts printed documentation. More maps can be found in Series 4, Sub-series 7: Maps.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This sub-series has is arranged in alphabetical order.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This sub-series is open for research.

"Plan of Land belonging to Tufts College in Medford & Summerville", circa 1856. "A Map of the Ground of Tufts College" circa 1928. "Plan of Land in Medford & Somerville on the Westerly Slope of Winter Hill", circa 1875 – 1890 (date based on name of train station map). "Plan No. 5 of Land in Medford owned by William Tufts and others", circa 1861. "Plan No. 6, Land in Medford Owned by George F. Tufts", circa 1861-1900. "Plan No. 3. of Land in Medford belonging to Wm Tufts & others", circa 1854. "A Map of the Grounds of Tufts College", circa 1928. "Tufts College in Medford and Boston Mass", map, circa 1947.

Blake (1901 – 1987) for their achievements in the sciences and engineering.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains Roman, Greek and Saxon coins dating circa 335 BCE -- 1000 CE; European coins dating circa 1000 -- 1900 CE; and European, Asian, and African coins dating circa 1900 – 1961.

scopecontent.p: This box contains Roman, Greek, and Saxon coins dating circa 430 BCE -- 628 CE; European coins dating circa 979 -- 1324; and European, Asian, and South American coins dating circa 1547 -- 1995.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains Roman and Byzantine coins dating circa 338 BCE – 1203 CE; European coins dating circa 1289 – 1964; American coins dating circa 1850s; a few Mexican and Lebanese coins from dating circa 1950s; a Tufts commemorative coin, circa 1913; and a few unidentified coins.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains examples of cuneiform writing, scarabs, and a tomb figure of a pharaoh dating from circa 2150 BCE – 1924 BCE, as well as a Roman memorial slab dating circa 0100 CE.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: No order has been imposed on this series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: John W. Zarker, Chair of the Classics Department, Tufts University (1971-1989), identified and translated the inscription. He noted that the provenance of the slab is unknown other than a notation on the back of the stone casing reading 'Mavor Collection.' To the best of his knowledge this inscription has not been published. According to John Zarker, the names are not listed in Pauly-Wissowa nor in the usual epigraphical publications or prosopographies. Date is approximate. Full text (abbreviation supplied): [D(is)] M (anibus sacrum) [L(uci)] Herenni Pto lemaei Miles C(lassis) P(raetoria) M(isenensis) (e) III (triere) Lucifero Nat(us) Aegypti Mil(itavit) an(nis) XXV Vix(it) an(nis) XLIV T(itus) Iulius Numisian(us) III (trium) libero(rum) p9ater) her(es) b(ene) m(erenti) f(ecit)> Translation: This monument is sacred to the Gods of the Underworld of [Lucius} Herennius Ptolemaeus, a soldier of the praetorian fleet stationed at Misenum from the trireme Lucifer. Born in Egypt he was a soldier for twenty five years; he lived forty four years. Titus Iulius Numisianus, father of three children, as heir set up this monument for Herennius who well deserved it.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 1: The Small Tablet:

Introduction: This tablet is written in Sumerian, a language with no linguistic affiliation to any other language known to us. The script used is called cuneiform. The tablet itself can be dated to the Ur III period (ca. 2112-2004 BCE) of ancient Mesopotamia. It contains no further information for more precise dating, except that it was written in the 3rd month (about May-June) of a certain year. Based on the peculiar name of the month, this tablet may well have come from ancient Umma, a Ur III province approximately 300 km south of Baghdad today. In terms of genre, this tablet is an administrative document of the period, a period from which tens of thousands records like this tablet were preserved and a period that is considered one of the most richly documented era throughout the history of Mesopotamia.

Transliteration and Translation: Legends: ( )word not written down but implied [ ] broken and unrecognizable signs ? ? signs partly broken, but can be restored with certainty ? signs with uncertain reading ! signs not written in the way as might be expected from the context, probably resulting from the mistake or confusion of the scribe Capital Letters: literal reading of the sign, without really understanding its meaning in context Italicized Letters: Sumerian proper names adopted in English translation

1. 1 (bán) 5 sìla še lugal 10+5 liters of barley 2. UD? ŠA NI IB DU ? meaning of this line unclear 3. šà-gal-ne-ne as their fodder 4. a-hu-ma-ti Ahumati 5. kaskal-ta ì-im-du-a who will travel 6. šu ba-ti received (them) 7. iti še-kar-?ál Month III (Umma)
Identified and translated by Xiaoli Ouyang, a Ph.D. student working at the Harvard Semitic Museum, March/April 2006.

Because the cuneiform cone had never been clearly identified or translated (information was based on what the donor, J. Welch had sent with the items), Susanne Belovari, archivist for reference and collections, asked the Semitic Harvard Museum to look at the cone. This is how Ms. Ouyang came to identify and translate this and all other cuneiform.

2. The Medium-Sized Tablet: Introduction: This tablet is written in Sumerian and uses the cuneiform script. It dates to the Ur III period, more precisely, to the 8th month (about October-November) of the 8th year of Amar-Sîn, the third king of this dynasty (approx. mid-21st century BCE). Based on the appearance of Abbašaga, an official well-known in Puzriš-Dagan (modern Drehem, south of Baghdad today), this tablet could well have been excavated there. It is an administrative text concerning the withdrawal of domestic animals. Obv. 1. 5 udu 5 sheep 2. 5 máš-gal 5 (male) goats 3. me-dištaran Me'Ištaran ? 4. ?ìr a-na-ti sukkal conveyed by Anati, secretary; 5. lugal-kù-zu maškim Lugal-kuzu is the one who approves; 6. šà mu-DU lugal from the royal delivery; lower edge: ?ud?-25-kam on the 25th day; Rev. 7. ki ab-ba-ša6-ga-ta from Abbašaga ? 8. ba-zi withdrew. 9. blank 10. iti šu-eš5-ša Month VIII 11. mu en eriduki ba-hun AS 8

Explanation: Me-Ishtaran withdrew 5 sheep and 5 goats, either from a group of animals known as the royal delivery, or as part of his contribution to the royal delivery. They were conveyed by Anati and Lugal-kuzu approved this transaction.
Identified and translated by Xiaoli Ouyang, a Ph.D. student working at the Harvard Semitic Museum, March/April 2006.

Because the cuneiform cone had never been clearly identified or translated (information was based on what the donor, J. Welch had sent with the items), Susanne Belovari, archivist for reference and collections, asked the Semitic Harvard Museum to identify and transcribe this and all other cuneiforms.
3: an Egyptian clay tablet.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Top tray. The Well-Preserved Cone: Introduction: This cone is written in Sumerian and uses the cuneiform script. In ancient Mesopotamia, clay cones were often buried as foundation deposits for temples or palaces. Only gods were supposed to read them. This cone can be dated to the late 22nd century BCE, slightly before or contemporary with the Ur III period. Judging from its content, it must have been excavated at the site of Tello, situated in the South of raq today and the central part of a city-state named Lagaš. This text is a typical royal inscription, usually recording what a ruler does to please his god(s), so that the effort of the ruler can be recognized and reciprocated. 1. dnin-gír-su 2. ur-sa? kalag-ga 3. den-líl-lá-ra 4. gù-dé-a 5. énsi 6. lagaški-ke4 7. ní?-du7-e pa mu-na-è 8. é-ninnu dIM.DUGUDmušen-bábbar-ra-ni 9. mu-na-dù 10. ki-bi mu-na-gi4 Translation: For Ningirsu (tutelary god of Lagaš), valiant warrior of Enlil (head of the then pantheon), Gudea, governor of Lagaš, made things splendid as they used to be, built the temple Eninnu, his (=Ningirsu's) white thunder-bird (a metaphor referring to the temple), and restored it to its place. Identified and translated by Xiaoli Ouyang, a Ph.D. student working at the Harvard Semitic Museum, March/April 2006. Because the cuneiform cone had never been clearly identified or translated (information was based on what the donor, J. Welch had sent with the items), Susanne Belovari, archivist for reference and collections, asked the Semitic Harvard Museum to identify and transcribe this and all other cuneiforms. late 22nd century, BCE

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Top tray. The Biggest Tablet: Introduction: This tablet is written in Sumerian and uses the cuneiform script. It can be dated to the Ur III period, but except for this, no further information about dating is available. As for provenance, it should come from southern Mesopotamia. It seems to deal with withdrawal of flour, butter, beer and beer-related material from warehouses located in different places. Obv. 1. […] zì-kala [X liters] of kala-flour 2. […] sìla zú-lum X liters of dates 3. […] eša 2 (bán) […] X (liters) of eša-flour (and) 20 liters of … 4. […] ?sìla? ì-nun 2 sìla ?kaš!? […] X liters of butter and 2 liters of beer 5. 1 sìla ?eštin-babbar 1 sìla kaš! še 1 liter of white wine and 1 liter of barley beer 6. 1 (bán) kaš! sig5 1 (bán) kaš!-ge6 ?sig5? 10 liters of high-quality beer and 10 liters of high-quality beer 7. šà é-duru5 ZÌ (from) the village; 8. 3 (bán) zì-kala 5 sìla zú-lum 30 liters of kala-flour and 5 liters of dates 9. 1 (bán) eša 2 (bán) zì še 10 liters of eša-flour and 20 liters of barley flour 10. 1 sìla ì-nun 1 sìla kaš sig7 1 liter of butter and 1 liter of malted? beer 11. 1 sìla kaš! še 3 (pi) 2 (bán) dida ?in-a 1 liter of barley beer and 200 liters of ordinary malt 12. šà kisal from the Courtyard; 13. 2 (bán) zì-kal 2 sìla zú-lum 20 liters of kala-flour and 2 liters of dates 14. 2 sìla eša 3 sìla zì-še 2 liters of eša-flour and 3 liters of barley Flour 15. 1/2 sìla ì-nun 1/2 sìla kaš!-sig7? Half a liter of butter and half a liter of malted beer 16. 1/2 sìla kaš! še 3 (pi) 1 (bán) dida ?in-a Half a liter of barley beer and 190 liters of ordinary malt 17. ki ki? […] A AŠ from…; 18. 2 (bán) ?eša? […] zì še 20 liters of eša-flour X …barley flour The reverse is too broken to read. Identified and translated by Xiaoli Ouyang, a Ph.D. student working at the Harvard Semitic Museum, March/April 2006. Because the cuneiform cone had never been clearly identified or translated (information was based on what the donor, J. Welch had sent with the items), Susanne Belovari, archivist for reference and collections, asked the Semitic Harvard Museum to identify and transcribe this and all other cuneiforms. Date is approximate: 2112-2004 BCE

did.unittitle: Tomb figure of Pharaoh Setekhy I

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Top tray. Documentation (in file) has history of Egypt, ca. 1375-1202 BC.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Top tray. The Largely Reddish Cone: Introduction: This text uses the cuneiform script and is written in Akkadian, the earliest attested Semitic language. It can be dated to the reign of Lipit-Ištar (ca. 1934-1924 BCE), a ruler of the city-state Isin during the Isin-Larsa period, when various local powers in southern Mesopotamia proper and on its periphery fought with each other for hegemony after the collapse of the Ur III dynasty. This period ends when Hammurabi reunited southern Mesopotamia around 1750 BCE and brought the Old Babylonian Kingdom to its heyday. The signs on this cone are too broken to read. But based on parallels, the text supposedly records that Lipit-Ištar fashioned a pair of pot stands dedicated to the god Enlil and goddess Ninlil, the leading couple of the then pantheon. Identified and translated by Xiaoli Ouyang, a Ph.D. student working at the Harvard Semitic Museum, March/April 2006. Because the cuneiform cone had never been clearly identified or translated (information was based on what the donor, J. Welch had sent with the items), Susanne Belovari, archivist for reference and collections, asked the Semitic Harvard Museum to identify and transcribe this and all other cuneiforms. Date is approximate: 1934-1924 BCE

did.unittitle: Manuscript, printed, and book history materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains manuscripts, prints, and book history materials dating circa 0100 – 2007. Manuscripts includes documents written on papyrus, illuminated manuscript leaves, leaves from religious texts, corresondence, and speeches. Printed material includes governmental records from the US, Britain, and Russia; leaves from religious texts as well as early printed books, some with woodblock illustrations; correspondence; and newspapers. There are also hand-drawn and printed maps, as well as illustrative and photographic prints. The book history material consists of type-writers and book binding material.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged into 10 sub-series: Autographed letters collection; Book history materials; Ephemera; Government records; Illuminated and early manuscripts; Manuscripts; Maps; Papyrus; Printed materials; and Prints.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This series is open for research.

did.langmaterial: The majority of the materials in the sub-series are in English with one letter in German.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains correspondence and photographs signed by notable figures dating circa 1812 – 1965. People of note represented in this sub-series include Albert Einstein, Charles Dickens, and Jack London.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This sub-series is arranged roughly alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains original manuscript and copies of correspondence from minor luminaries such as John F. Kennedy, Marie Curie, Herbert Hoover, and Mary S. Livermore to Tufts affiliated people such as Henry W. Holmes, John Albert Cousens, and Joseph Homidar.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains photographs and prints, some signed, of several minor luminaries such as Phillips Brooks, Schuyler Colfax, and George S. Boutwell.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains typewriters and book binding materials dating circa 1819 – 1960.

scopecontent.p: In heavy tweed patterned case with attached key. Found uncataloged in the stacks in the winter of 2009. Speculation that it was John Holmes's typewriter at one time, but the provenance is unclear.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In wooden case. Found uncatalogued in the stacks in the winter of 2009. User manual, instructions, and spare parts were also found with the typewriter. The provenance is unclear.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains printed ephemera dating circa 1893 – 1898. This includes a postcard and ticket from the World's Columbian Expositions dated 1893; four Apache playing cards dated circa 1898; and stamps illustrating the Stamp Act, undated.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: No order has been imposed on this sub-series.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This sub-series is open for research.

did.langmaterial: The majority o fthe materials in this sub-series are in English with some in Russian.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains governmental records from Great Britain, Russia, and the United States dating circa 1600 – 1945. These records include royal declarations and proclamations from Great Britain; a Russian military order; American WWII bond posters and WWI military envelopes; a Massachusetts treasury certificate; American documents describing land ownership; and a complaint and warrant filed against David Kelly in Kingston, New Hampshire.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This sub-series is arranged chronologically.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This sub-series is open for research.

did.langmaterial: The majority of the materials in this sub-series are in English with a document in Latin and another document in Hebrew.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains manuscripts written circa 1698 – 1999. These manuscripts mainly consists of correspondence dating circa 1698 – 1891. Also included in this subseries are a Fourth of July speech dated 1813; fragments of a journal dating 1774 and a report dating 1860; an "I owe you" document dating 1772; two handwritten lists dating circa 1780 – 1860; a copy of a prophecy by Mother Shipton (1488 – 1561) dating circa 1862; and a page from a Patrick family Bible dating circa 1775 -- 1809. There is also a Megillah scroll written in Hebrew from the 19th or 20th century.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This sub-series is arranged roughly chronologically.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This sub-series is open for research.

did.unittitle: Mathew Bryant "I owe you" to John Dudley on behalf of Jacob Currier

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original housing note: "Writ and documents in case of Jacob Currier, who in 1792 was fined 4 shillings for profane swearing by Josiah Bartlett J.P. J. B.'s autograph (signer of Decl. of Ind.)

did.unittitle: Extract from the journal of Thomas Hutchinson
Page from a Patrick family Bible
Letter by Blodgett to Mr. Miner grant
Fragment of a report about Guiseppe Mazzini

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The fragment was found in the former Ryder collections in 2011: processing of the socalled Ryder collection revealed that over decades historical material was added to the Ryder collection rather arbitrarily. When reprocessing the Ryder archives, material that was clearly not related to the Ryder donation, was pulled and either formed new collections or added to the AC collection when we had absolutely no information about provenance; processed by Susanne Belovari May 2012. Date is approximate since the last page mentions his actions in 1860 and uses the present tense to describe Mazzini's behavior and Mazinie died in 1872. 12 page handwritten fragment, missing first page/s and perhaps missing last page/s summarizing Mazzini's achievements and actions from at least 1832 to 1860. Giuseppe Mazzini (1805-1872) was an Italian poilticians, journalist and activist and detrimental in unifying Italy and supporting movements for popular democracy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The fragment was found November 29 2005 when Tisch Library staff completed their research for a civil war related exhibit. List of historical items such as album of Continental Currency or lottery ticket Harvard College 1794. We are unable to ascertain provenance of list and therefore added it to AC/ collection; Susanne Belovari, Archivist for Reference and Collections, October 2012.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Date is approximate. The prophecy was found in the former Ryder collections in 2011: processing of the socalled Ryder collection revealed that over decades historical material was added to the Ryder collection rather arbitrarily. When reprocessing the Ryder archives, material that was clearly not related to the Ryder donation, was pulled and either formed new collections or added to the AC collection when we had absolutely no information about provenance; processed by Susanne Belovari May 2012. Handwritten copy of a fake prophecy first published in 1641, 80 years after the death of Ursula Southill [Ursula Soothtell or Ursula Sontheil] known as Mother Shipton. This version ending with the lines 'The world to an end shall come In eighteen hundred and eighty one.' was written by Charles Hindley in 1862.

did.unittitle: Henry Busch letter to Reverend E. G. Brooks

scopecontent.p: Top tray. Scroll is handwritten on parchment in Hebrew; the story of Queen Esther, Mordecai and King Ahasuerus, Persian King. The silver case is embellished with symbls of the Tuseves tribes.

did.unittitle: Loose leaves from exhibit about history of writing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains mainly printed leaves and facsimiles in Latin, Hebrew, and English, with one illuminated manuscript in Arabic.

did.langmaterial: This sub-series contains materials in German, English, French, Latin, and Flemish.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains printed and hand drawn maps dating circa 1586 – 1947. Most of the maps date from the 1800s and depict European countries. These maps also depict the African, Asian, European, North America, and South America continents as well various islands including the British Isles and East Indian Islands. Some maps of European and American cities can be found in this subseries, including printed and hand-drawn maps of the Tufts campus and the surrounding areas dating 1852 – 1947.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: No order has been imposed on this sub-series.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This sub-series is open for research.

did.unittitle: Map of Essex County, compiled from the latest Authorities by James G. Carter. Boston: Published by Carter and Hendee. [with Statistical Table of Essex County]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There are two copies of this map, one slightly damaged. The tag on the back of one of the maps gives the cataloging number 1552, the map was then dated via other cataloging numbers from the same period. These documents were found uncatalogued in the stacks in January 2009.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Inventory is as follows: ABC The Pathfinder Railway Guide Map Eastern Section. Rippey's Index Map of Lowell, Mass. 1888. Metropolitan Sewerage Commissioners, Plan of Charles and Neponset River Valleys Showing District to be Considered in Studies Relating to High Level Gravity Sewer Boston, Massachusetts 1899. Map of the City of Worcester 1902. Map of the City of Brockton 1889. Map of the Metropolitan Sewerage District Boston, Massachusetts September 30, 1899. Map of the City of Boston and Vicinity 1902. Clayton, New York 1903. Map of Newton. Map of the Fitchburg Hoosac Tunnel Route and Its Connections. ABC The Pathfinder Railway Guide Map Western Section. Supply and Distribution Systems of the Public Waterworks of Winchester, Mass. December 31, 1894. Map of Weymouth, Mass. 1907. City of Medford Map Showing Medford Sewerage System March 1, 1894. Metropolitan Sewerage Commissioners, Plan Showing Outlet of Nut Island, Recommended for High Level Gravity Sewer, Boston, Mass. 1899. Map of the City of Medford 1897. [Unlabeled: New Hampshire, Maine Railway Map]. [Unlabeled: Partial Pathfinder Eastern Seaboard].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains maps of the African, Asian, European, North American, and South American continents as well as maps of most of the European countries, Canada, India, the British Isles, and the East Indian Islands, dating circa 1782 -- 1877. There are also maps of cities such as Berlin, Delhi, London, New York City, and Pairs, dating circa 19th century. Of note in this folder are a map of the Americas dated 1676 and "A General Chart on Mercator's Projection to shew the Track of the Lion and Hindonstan from England to the Gulf of Pekin in China, and their return to England with the statement of the barometer and thermometer, containing also the limits of the Chinese Empire, as extended by the conquest of the present Emperor Chen-Lung (Quianlong)" dated circa 1735 -- 1796 (the reign of Quianlong).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Inventory is as follows: Map of west coast of Europe including the British Isles, undated. Map of the globe in French, circa 1760. Map of the globe in Latin circa 1742. "The Idle Prentice Executed at Tyburn" hand-colored print, circa 1747. Maps of England circa 1646 and 1650. Map of Spain circa 1586. Map of Scotland circa 1636 (Latin). Map of Italy circa 1682 (English). Map of the bay between Gravelines and Dunkirk, France, circa 1642.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains maps with a few prints and some printed leaves dating circa 1780 – 1947. Most of the maps date from the 1800s and depict Europe and the United States. There are also maps of specific U.S. states such as Virginia and Maryland, and cities such as Boston, London, and Charlestown. There are also a few maps of British counties dating from 1947 as well as a map of Africa, undated. Of note in this folder are a map of Medford dated 1880 and a hand drawn map of Boston's western suburbs highlighting rivers and roads, undated.

did.unittitle: Hand-drawn maps of the Mill pond area in Boston, MA and ship's log

did.langmaterial: The language and script of these materials has not been positively identified but is most likely Egyptian.

did.unittitle: An example of Coptic writing on papryrus, Egypt

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series consists of printed texts dating circa 1478 – 1893. Most of the materials in this series are printed leaves from religious, some with woodblock illustrations, or early texts as well as facsimiles of the same. There are also correspondence, newspapers, and speeches in this series.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This sub-series is arranged chronologically.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This sub-series is open for research.

El Porvenir de Bisayas, 10th vol, no. 1790

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Newspaper from Iloilo, Phillipines. Issue was found in the 'Ryder Collection of Confederate Archives' in 2011; the Ryder collection was cataloged as part of the WPA in 1939/1940 but in later decades the catalog ( A Calendar of the Ryder Collection of the Confederate Archives at Tufts College 1940) was forgotten and library staff added other materials to the Ryder collection, usually items from the South, from the 18th and 19th century and around the time of the Civil War. Because the newspaper is not part of the original Ryder collection and no relationship to any other former Ryder items could be discerned, the item was moved to the AC collection in spring 2012, Susanne Belovari

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains illustrative and photographic prints as well as a painting on canvas dating circa 1741 – 2007. The prints include reproduction and original art prints; portraits; and prints depicting citiy scenes.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: No order has been imposed on this subseries.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This sub-series is open for research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original prints removed from map case (room 10), drawer #25. Set of 8 Prints by David Azuz, numbered 36 of 300. 15 prints by B. Gold. 1 Print by Ivan Generalic, numbered 7 of 239 "A Large Rooster on a Stick".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The folder contains prints and a painting on canvas, dating circa 1872 – 1981. The original prints include a print of the Capital Building, undated; a Japanese print, undated; a portrait of Paul Fourmarier, 1934; Gilbert Stewart's George Washington portrait, undated; as well as other prints depicting city scenes and buildings. There are also about seven prints reproducing drawings by Kathe Kollwith, circa 1943.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains prints depicting London from several publishers and artists, dating circa 1741 – 1841; printed leaves, undated; a printed portrait of Robert Hermann Schomburgk, dated 1840; a photograph of a statue of the Goddess Athena, undated; and a printed portrait of a man sitting on a bench, undated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains portraits, paintings, and sculptures dating circa 1863 – 1970. Items depict notable men and literary figures including Francis Parkman (1863); Jack London (1913); and Moby Dick (circa 1970).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: No order has been imposed on this series.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This series is open for research.

Any relationship Francis Parkman had with Tufts remains unknown. The item was originally framed by Dodge, Collier and Perkins [115 Washington St., Boston]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains artifacts dating circa 1600 – 1950 accrued by Digital Collections and Archives over time. These artifacts include a bamboo pipe flute, a cannon ball, memorabilia from the National Congress for the League of Nations, research notes on the history of apples, and a silver cup.
